Posts.Content: Haha I know that one so well. I asked my husband to hoover  yesterday (find it makes my recent surgical wounds sore). His reply "but I did it last week".... Arghhhhhhhh! x
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: Hi Daisy. I'm a nurse too and can completely relate to your experience.... I picked up on so many clues from the first doctor who examined me at the hospital (the look on her face) through 4 mammograms on the right side where I hadn't even found the lump, ultrasound guided biopsies and then the arrival of the breast care nurse before I was called back in.... It all seemed like such bad news. On a positive note I can say I have had fantastic care from my local hospital. The treatment wasn't fun but it was doable and made so much better by my having people looking after me that I trust. Makes such a difference. I've always been proud to work for the NHS and having now been on the other side as a patient that has been reinforced many times over. This website has been a life saver too. Sensible sane advice when I couldn't think straight enough to make sensible decisions about myself! The support on every level is amazing although I do think women, generally, are fab at supporting each other... Good luck to you Daisy, whatever the outcome on Tuesday. Love Debbie XX
Posts.Title: New diagnosis but already knew

Posts.Content: Thank you for a lovely happy post. I felt the same out horse-riding this morning in the sunshine . We're also going on a family holiday to Yorkshire dales tomorrow. Can't wait as last year was a complete write off. Wishing you lots more happy evenings! Love Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Happy stuff

Posts.Content: Hi I'd say it is totally normal to get the miseries sometimes. Chemotherapy, surgery and radiotherapy take a huge toll on our bodies. My last chemotherapy was on 28th September and it's only been in the last week or so that I'm feeling more like my usual cheerful, optimistic and energetic self. I also had FEC-T. I'm with you on the "Oh don't you look well" comments! Must admit with a bit of make up on I can convince myself I don't look so much like we should be calling an undertaker any time soon! Seriously though it is amazing to see what the body can cope with and still stage a recovery! Wishing you a very Merry Christmas and a Happy Healthy New Year. Debbie xxxx
Posts.Title: The Miseries

Posts.Content: I had a double mastectomy with immediate reconstruction with implants April 2015. I also felt very tight and painful across my chest for several months afterwards although it does gradually ease. I found doing the exercises helped a lot. After about 6 months I could comfortably lie face down without any issues and don't feel I have any restrictions on my lifestyle. Went back to horse riding after six weeks. I did find the numbness very odd to start with across my chest,armpits and back of my arms. Some sensation has returned in my arms and armpits but not significantly across my chest but it doesn't bother me in the least now. So yes it will stop hurting and you will get back to doing the things you want to do - plus a few I could have cheerfully not gone back to like hoovering! I did manage to string that out for quite a while although when my family realised I was mucking out horses and riding they did get wise to me haha! Hang on in there; it will get better. Hugs to you, Debbie xxxx
Posts.Title: Falling to pieces

Posts.Content: I feel I could have written this myself Fiona (although not with so much eloquence!). Lovely words. Thank you for sharing them. I came up with a long list of positives that came out of having breast cancer which shocked some people. One positive was fully appreciating how kind people could be and this extends to this site. I have been overwhelmed that people take the time to respond to my questions and for the hope I have gained from so many people.  Good luck with your last treatment Fiona. My daughter plucked up courage to attend my last one with me; she's 17. I think she found it very reassuring. A big step up from when I was first diagnosed! Love Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Farewell to Chemo!

Posts.Content: Hi. I had a few brave hairs growing during the Docetaxel. Last dose 28th September 2015.By Christmas I felt I had just enough hair to go out without a hat/scarf. My hair is very fine, always has been, but there does seem to be more of it! It's much darker - I was blonde before. It's also wavy. After about 5 months I had a really good covering of short hair. It doesn't seem to grow very quickly but I'm just so pleased to have hair again. Best wishes, Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Question about hair growth

Posts.Content: Hi Lizzy. My first appointment was also late in the day and they were running around 40 minutes late. It lasted about 20 minutes. I was told what to expect from the chemotherapy and given information sheets. The nurse also gave me a tour of the chemotherapy suite. Good luck Lizzy. Chemotherapy isn't fun but you will get through it and out the other side. Love Debbie xx
Posts.Title: First Oncology Appointment

Posts.Content: Fantastic news JJ. You certainly deserve some fun again! Will watch out for your blog. Hope you have the most fabulous time! Love Debbie xxxx
Posts.Title: Nearly there

Posts.Content: Hi Claire. It might be worth asking for a swab to be taken to make sure it is a fungal infection. I found rinsing my mouth out with Difflam and Corsodyl helped. Eating pineapple and live yoghurt also soothed it. Hope it's better soon. Love Debbie xx
Posts.Title: 2 months after chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Rachel I had a bilateral mastectomy with immediate implant reconstruction 2 years ago. Like you I'm a keen horse rider and didn't want scars anywhere else or a long recovery and possible loss of strength. I'd be devastated if I couldn't do all the heavy work associated with looking after a horse! I was told I probably wouldn't be able to ride for 6 months but have to confess I was back on board after 6 weeks. Very naughty but in my defense I did ride the horse I share with a friend who I know well and is pretty bomb proof. My husband caught her, groomed and tacked up so all I had to do was get on from the mounting block. We then went out for a plod around the local tracks with my husband on foot. All very sedate but, boy, did it give me a lift! I drove after a month and was out walking a week after the op. To be honest walking was easier than getting out of bed as I had 4 drains initially! I'm used to be very physically active so did feel quite an invalid at first but gradually things improved and I was able to look back and appreciate how far I'd come in a few short weeks. The first 2 days post op were the worst in so far as pain went and I accepted all the medication I could have but I still managed to hobble around the ward.By the 4th day I was walking around the hospital. My consultant found me in the hospital canteen and decided I should go home! After the first few days Paracetamol was sufficient for pain relief and anyway I hated the Codeine as I felt spaced out and got constipated. Your list and other peoples suggestions seems to have most things covered. The very best of luck to you. Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Pre-mastectomy and implant recon nerves

Posts.Content: Hi Blue  I have exactly the same issue. Have you tried your GP's Practice Nurse or phlebotomist? The only people who will do mine are my work colleagues (I'm a Practice Nurse). I did try to do my own as I'm also happy to do feet/ankles but I was too cowardly! If it's the hospital that need the test you'll need to ask them for a request form to take to whoever will do your test for you. Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Blood tests in foot due to node removal on both sides.

Posts.Content: Hi Pam. You are,most definitely, not being silly! I had a melt down from the minute I was diagnosed and didn't feel more in control until a few weeks after my surgery. It all takes time to sink in and, for me, waiting for results and then surgery was horrible. It's a year today since I had a double mastectomy. My hospital let me keep my own knickers on but if yours doesn't I'll bet they have some to fit... Big hugs for you, love Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Having a meltdown

Posts.Content: My oncology nurse said there was no good research to support the argument either way for eating or avoiding live yoghurt. I had already looked myself. As I'd had oral thrush during chemotherapy I decided to try it and felt so much better for it. I ate live yoghurt and also had one of the probiotic drinks every day and still do. Had my last Doxcetaxel 28th September. Good luck x
Posts.Title: Dietary advice

Posts.Content: Hi It may be worth seeing your GP as it may be something unrelated to your surgery or medication and they will, probably, be able to give you something to stop the nausea. Hope you feel better soon. Debbie x
Posts.Title: anyone else sick after surgery

Posts.Content: No you're not being over sensitive. I had exactly the same reaction when I heard this particular news item. Like so many others on here. I was fit,slim,non smoker,little alcohol,very healthy diet etc etc.  To hear it's probably our fault is not helpful on any level. As it's an American study I feel it has less credibility however Merry Christmas to you all and wishing you a Happy Healthy New Year! Lots of love Debbie x
Posts.Title: Cancer is our own fault

Posts.Content: Good news Peaches and fingers crossed for next week for you. I've also made a decision to enjoy feeling well again loving life rather than worry about what might happen in the future. Love Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Feeling pleased

Posts.Content: Well I had my scan yesterday - they just did an ultrasound in the end. Turns out the lump is "pectoral muscle insertion". To say I am relieved and ecstatically happy is an understatement... Dxxx
Posts.Title: portacath scar tissue or a recurrence

Posts.Content: Hi Alison I'm doing well thanks. On the waiting list for more plastic surgery for reconstruction but that doesn't scare me like the cancer treatment! It's a long process but I'm amazed by my body's capacity to recover and repair. When I first found this forum I was so envious of everyone further down the road than me. Reading the questions from newer members makes me want to write something they will find encouraging to help them as others have helped me. Sometimes difficult to know what to say however as we're all so different.. Love Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Thank you ALL

Posts.Content: My eyelashes started to return around 12 weeks after my last chemotherapy (FEC-T) I was ecstatic! They did thin out again a few weeks later and I thought they were all going but are now looking good again and, dare I say it, back to normal! Love Debbie xx
Posts.Title: EYELASHES!

Posts.Content: I had my last chemotherapy 28/09/15 and then had my portacath removed early December 2015. A couple of weeks ago I found a broad bean size lump on my chest wall just below and more central than the site of my portacath. I mentioned it to my surgeon last week and she's arranging an MRI scan. I'm now quite tearful thinking it could be a recurrence and just wondered if anyone else had had a similar lump after having a port removed? Thank you in anticipation. Debbie x
Posts.Title: portacath scar tissue or a recurrence

Posts.Content: Thank you for replying ladies. I'm trying to put my concerns in the "I'll worry about it if and when I need to" box. Sometimes easier said than done... I saw my surgeon on the 29th March so hoping I get an appointment through for the MRI soon. Love to you all. Debbie XX
Posts.Title: portacath scar tissue or a recurrence

Posts.Content: I couldn't agree more Frankie. What a lovely post to share. You're so right in all you say. I was diagnosed March 2015. Merry Christmas and a very Happy Healthy New Year to you. Love Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Thank you ALL

Posts.Content: Got the appointment through for my MRI next Tuesday morning the 12th. Fingers crossed! Love to you all. Debbie xx
Posts.Title: portacath scar tissue or a recurrence

Posts.Content: Hi. Congratulations on the clear MRI. That really is very good news. I understand what you mean about wanting your old life back. The reality is, of course, that we can't. The only thing I can say is that, for me, 2 years on I don't fret about it nearly so much as I used to. Time really does help and that can't be hurried along.  I was having a lovely day a few months ago and thinking how good I felt when a nagging doubt entered my brain say "yes but what if it comes back?" Almost at the same moment I thought I'm not giving in to that thought. Today I am well and I'm not going to spoil today worrying about something that may never happen. If the worst does happen I'll deal with it again.... It seemed to have been a turning point for me. Maybe consider having some counselling? Hugs to you. Debbie x
Posts.Title: Dealing with uncertainty

Posts.Content: Thanks for your reply Sarah. Good to hear from you but sorry you've also suffered. I was diagnosed in March this year.Bilateral mastectomies with immediate reconstruction in April and chemotherapy June to September. During my chemo I had trouble with abscesses on the right side and ended up having to have the right implant out in October sadly. At least the scary cancer treatment is done even if I do have more surgery to go for reconstruction next year. I'm also on Tamoxifen. Wishing you well for the future Sarah Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Different cancer in each breast

Posts.Content: Hi. I was diagnosed with TNBC in March 2015 and at the same time they found an oestrogen positive primary in the other breast. Just curious and wondered if anyone else has had two different primaries diagnosed at the same time - not necessarily the same as me? Debbie x
Posts.Title: Different cancer in each breast

Posts.Content: Brilliant Lynn! Massive congratulations. That's an impressive list! Love Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Finished at last!!!!

Posts.Content: I felt exactly the same. Waiting for results drove me crazy. There wasn't room in my brain for anything else! Once I'd got the results and knew I had to have a double mastectomy (no choice as I had several lumps in both and 2 different primaries) I felt so much better. Once you have a plan this time will fade into insignificance. Big hugs to you and sorry you're having to go through this too. Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Waiting for results a nightmare

Posts.Content: I had a broad bean size lump appear just above where my right boob used to be. Two weeks of panic waiting for an ultrasound and it turned out to be the "pectoral muscle insertion" so innocent....and breathe... Sending you a hug as the waiting is awful.. Good luck and let us know how you get on.. Love Debbie
Posts.Title: Another Lump

Posts.Content: Hi again Carole Shame you have to wait for results as it's a tough call. Sending you hugs. Hope you're not too bruised.. Love Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Another Lump

Posts.Content: What a lovely post. Well done Mike! Good luck with your return to competitions. Debbie xx
Posts.Title: From cancer to cross-country. A positive post.

Posts.Content: I've been told 6-8 weeks before I might return to work (I'm a nurse) and up to a month before I can drive. I am concerned it will affect some activities as I'm a keen horse rider. Anyone with experience of LD flap plus implant able to comment? Best wishes Jj1, Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Latimmus flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: I use a soft falsie pinned into tops with a hidden support bit in them. Works well for sports! The falsie is the one I was given immediately post op. The only problem I have, especially before my expander went in, is that the elastic bit in the t shirt tends to ride up with the falsie as there's not much to hold it in place! Good luck. Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Prosthetics without a bra

Posts.Content: Hi chelseabun.  I had a bilateral mastectomy and immediate implant reconstruction 2 years ago. I was told I would need 3 months off work (I'm a nurse).  Unfortunately I got an infection around one of the implants during chemotherapy so it had to be removed. Last July I had an expander put in and next week I'm due to have both implants changed. The expander has been no problem at all. Little hard and tight now it's at full expansion but I'm still working, cycling, horse riding etc. Have a look on the Keeping Abreast website for advice as well. Good luck! Debbie x
Posts.Title: Reconstruction with expanders

Posts.Content: Hi CB. I'm having both implants changed as I prefer the shape of the round expander to the original tear drop shape I had so swapping both for round implants to be the best match. They'll never be exactly like my own boobs but in some ways they're better as they won't droop and I can go braless! Hope you have a great bank holiday weekend! Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Reconstruction with expanders

Posts.Content: Hi Swirly I wear a Racesafe body protector for horse riding which is as comfortable as it always was. I have one silicone implant and one expander filled with saline currently. Love the idea they might actually protect my ribs Helen! Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Watersports after treatment

Posts.Content: Thank you Julia. That has made my day! The last year has been one hell of a ride but I'm coming out the other side feeling happy and healthy! Working full time again and cycling there every day (10 mile round trip). Helping my friend with her horses and riding as often as I can. Looking forward to the rest of my life! Go me! Xxxx
Posts.Title: 1 year on...

Posts.Content: I know this has been asked before but it's 1 year tomorrow, 5th March, that I was told I had breast cancer in both sides.. So does that make me a 1 year survivor tomorrow or 20th April when I had bilateral mastectomy or 28th September when I had my last of 6 FEC-T? This site has been a constant source of excellent advice and comfort over the last year and I will, forever, be grateful to all of you who bother to answer the many questions posed!  Wishing you all many happy healthy years ahead of you. With love, Debbie xx
Posts.Title: 1 year on...

Posts.Content: Thank you Stawb11 Have added champagne to today's shopping list! Debbie xx
Posts.Title: 1 year on...

Posts.Content: Fantastic news! I had surgery before chemotherapy so will never know if the drugs worked but your success gives me great hope!  Debbie x
Posts.Title: biopsy results

Posts.Content: Fingers crossed for you J. I had bilateral mastectomy with immediate implant reconstruction last April. There were days I wondered if it was worth it but gradually bit by bit you will get better and stronger. Unfortunately I had chemotherapy after the op which resulted in abscesses around my right side implant which was eventually removed in October just after I finished chemotherapy. I'm now on the waiting list for an LD flap plus expander op. The left "breast" looks great. Different to the pre op me and it took a while to get used to how it looks but now I'm really pleased with it. Good luck tomorrow J. Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy and recon on Thursday sacred!!!!
